questions.text: A microbiologist was studying worms infecting the human body and discovered a flat, leaf-like species with an incomplete digestive system. To which of the following classes does this organism most likely belong?
questions.explanation:
Mode of Infection

Examples

Infective Form

Hosts

Ingestion of contaminated water/vegetation

Liver and intestinal flukes (e.g., Fasciola hepatica, Fasciolopsis buski)

Metacercaria

Definitive: Humans

Intermediate: Snails (primary), vegetation (secondary)

Consumption of raw/undercooked fish/crustaceans

Lung and liver flukes (e.g., Clonorchis sinensis, Paragonimus westermani)

Metacercaria

Definitive: Humans

Intermediate: Snails (primary), fish/crustaceans (secondary)

Skin penetration

Blood flukes (e.g., Schistosoma species)

Cercaria

Definitive: Humans

Intermediate: Snails

questions.text: Match the following trematode species with their primary habitat in the primary host. Trematode Species Primary Habitat 1. Fasciolopsis buski a. Bile ducts 2. Schistosoma mansoni b. Small intestine 3. Clonorchis sinensis c. Mesenteric veins 4. Paragonimus westermani d. Lungs

b. Small intestine

c. Mesenteric veins

d. Lungs

questions.text: Which of the following trematode species does not produce operculated eggs?
questions.explanation:
Trematode

Key Features

Sample Type

Schistosoma haematobium

Terminal spine at one end; found in urine

Urine

Schistosoma mansoni

Lateral spine on one side

Stool

Schistosoma japonicum

Rudimentary spine, often difficult to see

Stool

Fasciola hepatica

Operculum at one end; golden-brown

Stool

Paragonimus westermani

Thick shell, operculum present

Sputum/Stool

Clonorchis sinensis

Thickened rim around operculum; knob opposite operculum; embryonated

Stool

Opisthorchis spp.

Prominent operculum, embryonated

Stool

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents with complaints of abdominal pain, bloody diarrhea, and a recent onset of fatigue. He mentions that he has been working near freshwater lakes in an endemic region. A stool sample reveals Schistosoma eggs. Which of the following statements about Schistosoma species is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: The intermediate host for all Schistosoma species is a snail.

options.label: B
options.text: The life cycle of Schistosoma includes redia and metacercaria larvae.

options.label: C
options.text: Schistosoma japonicum primarily inhabits the superior mesenteric vein.

options.label: D
options.text: Schistosoma infections occur through skin penetration by cercaria larvae

questions.correct_answer: B. The life cycle of Schistosoma includes redia and metacercaria larvae.
questions.explanation:
Species

  • Schistosoma haematobium (Africa, Near East, Middle East, India)
  • Schistosoma mansoni (Africa, South America)
  • Schistosoma japonicum (China, Japan, Far East)

Habitat

  • S. haematobium: Veins of vesical and pelvic plexuses
  • S. mansoni: Inferior mesenteric vein
  • S. japonicum: Superior mesenteric vein (Option C)

Definitive Host

Man

Intermediate Host

Snail (Option A)

Mode of Infection

Skin penetration by cercaria (Option D)

Infective form

Cercaria larva

Eggs

Has characteristic lateral spine.

Larva

Has following stages: (Option B)

  • Miracida
  • Sporocysts
  • Cercaria: Has elongated ovoid body and forked tail.

Adult worm
  • Sexes are separate.
  • Has 2 muscular suckers: Oral and ventral sucker
  • Gynecophoric canal begins behind the ventral sucker, where the female worm is held.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents with painless hematuria and dysuria after returning from a trip to the Middle East. He reports swimming in freshwater lakes during his stay. Laboratory tests reveal eggs with a characteristic terminal spine in the urine. Which of the following is a potential complication of this condition?

options.label: C
options.text: Squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder

questions.correct_answer: C. Squamous cell carcinoma of the bladder
questions.explanation:
S. Haematobium

S. Mansoni

S. Japonicum
  • Swimmer’s itch
  • Painless hematuria, dysuria, proteinuria
  • Urinary bladder carcinoma: Squamous cell carcinoma > Transitional cell carcinoma (Option C)
  • Calculus formation
  • Chronic cystitis
  • Swimmer’s itch
  • Katayama fever: High fever, rash, arthralgia, hepatosplenomegaly, lymphadenopathy
  • Intestinal bilharziasis: Abdominal pain, bloody diarrhea (Option D)
  • Portal hypertension and periportal fibrosis.
  • Severe swimmer’s itch
  • Katayama fever in acute phase
  • Colicky abdominal pain, bloody diarrhea, anemia
  • CNS involvement: Severe epileptic seizures (Option A)
  • Lung involvement: Cor pulmonale,pulmonary hypertension.

Parasite

Associated Malignancy

Schistosoma haematobium

Urinary bladder cancer

Schistosoma japonicum

Colorectal cancer, metastatic lung cancer

Schistosoma mansoni

Colorectal cancer, hepatocellular carcinoma

Opisthorchis viverrini

Clonorchis sinensis

Opisthorchis felineus

Cholangiocarcinoma

Plasmodium species

Burkitt lymphoma

Strongiloides stercoralis

HTLV-1 induced lymphoma/leukemias

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with abdominal pain and bloody diarrhea after frequent exposure to freshwater while traveling in Africa. Stool examination reveals the presence of eggs with a characteristic lateral spine. Which of the following is inconsistent with this condition?

options.label: C
options.text: Swimmer’s itch due to cercarial penetration

options.label: D
options.text: Neurological deficit due to egg embolization

questions.explanation:
Intestinal Schistosomiasis

Urogenital Schistosomiasis
  • Caused by S. intercalatum, S. japonicum, S. mansoni and S. mekongi
  • Swimmer’s itch/Cercarial dermatitis (Option C ruled out)
  • Katayama fever (S. Japonicum > S. Mansoni): Serum sickness like illness with high fever, rash, arthralgia, hepatosplenomegaly, lymphadenopathy
  • Abdominal pain, bloody dysentery
  • Portal hypertension
  • Microabscess, granuloma, hyperplasia and eventually fibrosis of intestinal wall
  • Periportal fibrosis (clay pipestem fibrosis) (Option B ruled out)
  • Lung involvement: Cor pulmonale
  • CNS involvement: Severe epileptic seizures
  • Neurological deficit: Egg embolization (Option D ruled out)
  • Caused by S. haematobium
  • Swimmer’s itch/Cercarial dermatitis
  • Pulmonary symptoms: Cough, mild fever
  • Painless hematuria
  • Dysuria (Option A)
  • Proteinuria
  • Pseudoabscess in bladder
  • Fibrosis of vesical mucosa and formation of egg granuloma (sandy patches)
  • Recurrent UTI
  • Hydronephrosis
  • Hydroureter
  • Urinary bladder carcinoma: Squamous cell carcinoma > Transitional cell carcinoma
  • Chronic cystitis
  • Calculus formation

questions.text: The given image was seen during a microscopic examination of a sputum sample from a patient with a cough with associated hemoptysis. Identify the false statement.

options.label: B
options.text: It is the infective form of the causative agent

options.label: C
options.text: The mode of transmission is via ingestion

options.label: D
options.text: Crabs are second intermediate hosts, and humans are the definitive hosts

questions.correct_answer: B. It is the infective form of the causative agent
questions.explanation:
Paragonimus westermani / Lung fluke

  • This is a trematode which is also known as the oriental lung fluke.
  • It causes endemic hemoptysis in humans.

 

Epidemiology:

  • Global Prevalence: Approximately 22 million cases and 10 species infect humans.
  • Key Regions:
    • World: Predominantly found in the Far East (Korea, Japan, Taiwan, China, Philippines).
    • India: Endemic in Northeast states, particularly Manipur (prevalence: 6.7%).

Morphology

  • Adult worms: Leaf-like shape.
  • Eggs:
    • Operculated eggs. (Option A)
    • They are oval and golden brown.
    • Size: 80–120 µm × 45–65 µm.
    • Eggs are unembryonated when laid.
  • Larvae: Five developmental stages.

 

Hosts

(Option D)

  • Definitive host: Humans.
  • Intermediate hosts:
    • First: Snails.
    • Second: Crabs or crayfish.

Transmission

  • Infection occurs through ingestion of infected crabs/crayfishes carrying metacercariae (infective larvae).
  • Larvae penetrate the intestinal wall, enter the peritoneal cavity, and migrate to the lungs.
  • Adult worms produce eggs, which are expelled through sputum (commonly) or feces.

Pathogenicity and clinical features

Pulmonary paragonimiasis:

  • It causes eosinophilic granulomatous inflammation and cyst formation around worms, often in the right lung.
  • Symptoms:
    • Productive cough with brownish, blood-tinged sputum (offensive, fishy odor).
    • Possible frank hemoptysis and peripheral blood eosinophilia.
    • Chronic infections may lead to bronchitis, bronchiectasis, pneumonia, or lung abscesses.

Extrapulmonary paragonimiasis:

  • Worms may migrate to sites like the liver, spleen, abdominal wall, and occasionally the brain.
  • Forms:
    • Cerebral Paragonimiasis: this is a severe form.
    • Cutaneous Paragonimiasis: Migratory subcutaneous nodules and larva migrans.

Life cycle:

  • Definite host: Humans.
  • First intermediate host: Snails.
  • Second intermediate hosts: Crabs or crayfish. (option D)
  • Mode of transmission: Ingestion of metacercaria larvae in crayfish. (Option C)

 




 

Diagnosis

Sputum microscopy:

  • Collect early morning sputum samples.
  • Examine saline mount for operculated eggs.
  • Formalin-ether sedimentation technique is used for concentration.

Egg characteristics:

  • Shape: Oval, operculated, golden-brown.
  • Size: 80–120 µm × 45–65 µm.
  • Eggs are unembryonated when laid.

 

Serological tests:

  • Useful in early disease stages when microscopy is negative.
  • Antibody detection:
    • ELISA
    • Western Blot
  • Antigen Detection:
    • Dot ELISA

Other Diagnostic Tests:

  • Peripheral blood eosinophilia.
  • Radiological tests: MRI and CT scans for cyst localization; chest X-ray for pulmonary lesions.

Management

Treatment
  • Drug of Choice: Praziquantel (25 mg/kg/dose, three doses per day for 2 days).
  • Surgical Management: This may be necessary for severe pulmonary or cerebral lesions.

Prevention strategies
  • Sanitary disposal of sputum.
  • Control of snail populations.
  • Treatment of infected individuals.
  • Health education to raise awareness.

Parasites with operculated eggs

  • All Trematodes except Schistosoma species
    • Fasciola hepatica
    • Fasciola gigantica
    • Fasciolopsis buski
    • Clonorchis sinensis
    • Paragonimus westermani
    • Gastrodiscoides hominis
    • Opisthorcis felineus
    • Opisthorcis viverrini
    • Heterophyes heterophyes
  • Diphyllobothrium latum (Cestode)

questions.text: A 56-year-old male patient presents with jaundice, weight loss, and pruritus. Imaging studies reveal a mass in the bile duct, and ERCP demonstrates strictures and dilated bile ducts. Further investigations suggest an infectious etiology. Which of the following evolutionary stages of an organism and secondary intermediate host is responsible for this presentation?
questions.explanation:
Parasite

Clonorchis sinensis (Chinese liver fluke) is a parasitic fluke that causes clonorchiasis in humans.

Transmission

Acquired by consuming undercooked or raw freshwater fish contaminated with the parasite.

Morphology

Adult Fluke:

  • Flat, leaf-shaped; 10-25 mm in length and 3-5 mm in width.
  • Tapered anterior end and rounded posterior end.
  • Body covered with tegument bearing tiny spines.
  • Two suckers: oral sucker at the anterior end and ventral sucker (acetabulum) positioned further down.
 


 

Egg:

  • Oval, operculated (with a lid-like structure), yellow-brown in colour.
  • Distinct operculum at the anterior end and a small knob at the abopercular end.
 

Life Cycle

  

1. Egg Release: Infected individuals excrete eggs in feces, contaminating freshwater sources.

2. Snail Host: Eggs ingested by freshwater snails (first intermediate host) hatch and develop through stages: miracidia, sporocysts, rediae, and finally cercariae.

3. Fish Host: Cercariae are released from the snail into the water, where they seek and penetrate freshwater fish (second intermediate host), encysting as metacercariae in the fish’s muscle or skin.

4. Human Host: Humans become infected by consuming raw or undercooked fish containing metacercariae, which excyst, migrate to the bile ducts, and mature into adult flukes.

5. Egg Laying: Adult flukes in bile ducts lay eggs that are excreted in feces, completing the life cycle.

Presentation Features

Acute Infection: Symptoms are often mild or absent. When present, it may include right upper quadrant abdominal pain, fever, fatigue, nausea, diarrhea, and eosinophilia.

Chronic Infection: Long-term infections may lead to biliary obstruction, cholangitis, cholecystitis, or gallstones. Severe cases can cause liver cirrhosis, bile duct cancer (cholangiocarcinoma), and pancreatitis.

Investigations

1. Stool Examination: Microscopy for characteristic eggs in stool samples (primary diagnostic method; eggs may be scarce in light infections).

2. Duodenal Aspirate/Bile Examination: Detects eggs in bile samples or duodenal aspirates, helpful when stool examination is inconclusive.

3. Serology: Blood tests to detect antibodies or antigens specific to Clonorchis sinensis.

4. Imaging:

Ultrasound may show biliary dilatation or thickening, suggestive of chronic infection.

CT/MRI useful for identifying biliary obstruction, liver abnormalities, or cholangiocarcinoma in severe cases.

Management

Praziquantel (Drug of Choice): Dosage 25 mg/kg orally, three times daily for 2 days.

Alternative: Albendazole can be used if Praziquantel is contraindicated.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with right upper quadrant abdominal pain, jaundice, nausea, and a history of consuming contaminated water and aquatic vegetation while camping near a river. Physical examination reveals tenderness in the right upper quadrant and mild hepatomegaly. Laboratory tests show elevated liver enzymes and bilirubin, and stool examination reveals operculated eggs (as shown in the image). What is the best management strategy for this patient?

A 35-year-old man presents with complaints of abdominal pain, diarrhea, and significant weight loss over the past month. He recently traveled to a rural area where he ingested aquatic plants while swimming in a freshwater lake. On examination, he exhibits pallor and mild abdominal tenderness. A stool examination reveals the presence of eggs. Considering his symptoms and recent travel history, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Parasite

Fasciolopsis buski (Giant Intestinal Fluke) is a parasitic trematode infecting the small intestine of humans and pigs, causing fasciolopsiasis, leading to gastrointestinal symptoms and malabsorption.

Morphology

Adult:

  • Size: 20-75 mm in length.
  • Color: Brownish or yellowish.
  • Structure: Characteristic oral sucker at the anterior end for attachment; ventral sucker further down aids in feeding.
 

 

Egg:

  • Size: 130-140 micrometres in length, 80-85 micrometres in width.
  • Shape: Elliptical or oval.
  • Operculum: Possesses a lid-like structure at one end that opens when the egg is ready to release larvae.


 

Life Cycle
  1. Egg Stage: Eggs released in feces of infected humans or pigs, reach freshwater sources.
  2. Miracidium Stage: Eggs hatch into miracidia in water, which seek freshwater snails.
  3. Developmental Stages in Snail: Miracidia transform into sporocysts, rediae, and then cercariae.
  4. Metacercaria Stage: Cercariae encyst on aquatic plants, becoming metacercariae, infective to humans.
  5. Infection of Hosts: Humans/pigs ingest raw or undercooked aquatic plants with metacercariae.
  6. Adult Development: Metacercariae excyst in the small intestine, mature into adults, and lay eggs, completing the cycle.

Presentation Features

Acute Phase:

Symptoms appear 2-3 months after ingestion.

  • Abdominal Pain: Common, usually around the upper abdomen.
  • Diarrhea: Intermittent or prolonged.
  • Nausea and Vomiting: Frequent in heavy infections.
  • Malabsorption and Nutritional Deficiencies: Severe cases lead to growth retardation and edema, especially in children.

 

Chronic Phase:

Prolonged infection causes chronic diarrhea, weakness, and malabsorption due to the large size of flukes.

 

Eosinophilia: Elevated eosinophil count common in parasitic infections.

Investigations

Stool Examination: Primary diagnostic tool for detecting large, operculated eggs in fecal samples.

Serologic Tests: ELISA and immunodiagnostic tests, though less commonly used in endemic areas.

Imaging: Ultrasound or CT scans to detect adult flukes in cases of heavy infection or suspected obstruction.

Management

Pharmacological Treatment:

Praziquantel: Drug of choice for treating fasciolopsiasis, with a dosage of 25 mg/kg in a single dose.

Alternative Treatment: Triclabendazole, also effective but not universally available.
